abstracts.cdata!:
In regard to project performance
            assessment ratings, the China Environmental Technical
            Assistance Project had the following ratings: outcome was
            satisfactory; risk to development outcome was low; Bank
            performance was highly satisfactory; and borrower
            performance was highly satisfactory. Lessons learned from
            this assessment included: in large technical assistance
            projects, a programmatic approach may be preferred, with
            general agreement on overall objectives and a first year
            work-plan followed by iterative development of subsequent
            stages based on experience and changing circumstances;
            active involvement of functional or line departments can
            greatly raise the quality of outputs and development impacts
            of TA subprojects; in designing environmental
            capacity-building projects, the strengthening of
            sub-national environmental institutions is equally if not
            more important than that of the apex environmental agency;
            and passing-on IDA credits as a loan rather than as a grant
            to non-revenue-generating entitles creates distortions in
            priorities and work programs, as these entities shift their
            focus to seeking payments for services rather than
            conducting independent research.

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings convey highly satisfactory
            project outcomes, a highly likely sustainability, and
            substantial institutional development impacts; likewise,
            both performances by the Bank and Borrower are rated highly
            satisfactory. The reasons for success in technical
            assistance (TA) and capacity building projects outline five
            factors, namely, overall country policy and institutional
            capability, country income level, strong borrower ownership
            and implementing agencies managerial capacity, use of local
            consultants, and, intensive Bank supervision, all of which
            contributed to the success of the Project. Yet, regardless
            of success, several lessons suggest the following.
            Methodologies for project design, performance monitoring and
            evaluation, suggest that even newer mechanisms for project
            management are of limited and variable operational utility,
            unless a careful, selective approach is taken in designing
            them, and using them with common sense, as part of a shared
            effort at performance improvement over the long term, where
            indicators can make an important contribution to project
            effectiveness, and capacity development. Centralized
            procurement of scientific equipment seems to have been a
            problem, however, a decentralized approach might have been
            better, particularly given the large number of institutions
            involved, and a larger allowance provided for procurement on
            the basis of shopping. Notwithstanding, the success of the
            Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS) component emphasizes the
            value of designing such projects in an integrated way, to
            address all elements of the research agenda: upgrading
            facilities, procuring scientific equipment, computers and
            software, and, training personnel, with an emphasis on
            overseas training and increasing international cooperative research.

abstracts.cdata!:
This project is designed to support
            agreed environmental objectives through the provision of
            technical assistance to strengthen the capacities and
            selected policies and programs of two institutions of
            national importance in China's environment sector,
            National Environmental Protection Agency (NEPA) and the
            Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS). More specifically, it
            addresses identified needs that emerged from the
            Environmental Strategy Paper and its review with the
            Government. Those needs are: (a) to improve coordination of
            environmental monitoring and ecological research; (b) to
            promote cleaner industrial production, pollution prevention
            and waste minimization technologies; (c) to enhance economic
            policy instruments for pollution control, especially the
            pollution levy system; and (d) to strengthen the Chinese
            system of environmental assessments (EA). Another objective
            is to improve interagency and interministerial coordination
            for improved environmental management. The project consists
            of three main components: (i) CAS ecological research and
            monitoring which began in 1989 to design a Chinese Ecosystem
            Research Network (CERN) to strengthen long-term ecological
            research in China and to generate scientifically-valid
            ecological information that could be used for sustainable
            natural resource management and agricultural development;
            (ii) NEPA technical assistance program provides technical
            assistance; and (iii) environmental impact assessment system.
